title: Fatigue and Weakness in a Patient with Multiple Sclerosis
clinical_history: A 35-year-old female, diagnosed with relapsing-remitting Multiple Sclerosis (MS) 5 years ago, presents with complaints of fatigue, weakness, and numbness in her lower extremities. She reports difficulty walking and maintaining balance, which has worsened over the past 6 months. The patient has experienced two relapses in the past year, with the most recent one resulting in a 2-week hospital stay for acute exacerbation of MS symptoms.

nprs.affected_area: bilateral lower extremity weakness and fatigue
intermittent numbness and tingling in the legs

aggrevating_factors: prolonged walking, standing, or physical activity; high temperatures; stress
picture: A 24-hour picture of the patient's symptoms shows that her fatigue and weakness worsen throughout the day, with a significant increase in symptoms after lunch and in the late afternoon.
past_history: The patient has a history of optic neuritis in her left eye 3 years ago, which resolved with corticosteroid treatment. She has also experienced occasional bladder and bowel dysfunction.
medical_history: The patient has been taking disease-modifying therapy (DMT) for MS, specifically interferon beta-1a, for the past 5 years. She has also been managing her symptoms with physical therapy, occupational therapy, and lifestyle modifications.
medications: interferon beta-1a, baclofen for muscle spasms, and vitamin D supplements
personal_history: The patient is married with two young children and works part-time as a freelance writer. She has had to make significant lifestyle adjustments due to her MS diagnosis, including reducing her work hours and relying on her family for support.
imaging: MRI scans show multiple white matter lesions in the brain and spinal cord, consistent with MS.
